title: 107_s1733
content: The Act may be cited as the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" and includes provisions for an interoperable law enforcement and intelligence data system with name matching capacity and training. The "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" mandates the development of a unified electronic data system by key government agencies to access relevant information for visa issuance and alien admissibility. The system must have name matching capacity, linguistic search capability, user support, and private sector consultation. The unified electronic database mandated by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must be searchable on a linguistically sensitive basis, provide user support, consult with private sector firms, utilize commercially available platforms, and be continuously adjusted and improved based on experience and technological advancements. The database must use linguistically sensitive algorithms to account for variations in name formats and transliterations within a particular language. The unified electronic data system mandated by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must incorporate advanced linguistic, mathematical, statistical, and anthropological research methods. Linguistically sensitive algorithms must be developed for at least 4 high-priority languages designated by key government officials. Adequate user support must be provided with authoritative information on names in different languages, including gender identification. The "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" requires the provision of authoritative information on names in different languages, including gender identification. Reports on implementation progress must be submitted every 6 months to Congress by key government officials. The Director of Central Intelligence must issue a report within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of Central Intelligence must complete a survey and issue a report within 60 days of the enactment of the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001". Additionally, guidelines must be issued within 120 days, and appropriations are authorized for the implementation of the data system. Consultation with various government officials is required for the development and implementation of the system. In developing the data system, consultation is required with key government officials and agencies. The system must adhere to a specific technology standard and provide easy access to information for Foreign Service officers and Federal agents responsible for visa issuance and alien admissibility. Access to information is limited by certain officials. Access to intelligence information in the system is restricted by the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, and the Director of Central Intelligence.
